Great video! But bad sound. Allot of echo...

Congrats on that dramatic acting! The dramatization of car exhaust being, oh so horrifically toxic before the use of catalytic converters, was a bit much don’t you think?

Pretty sure people were not suddenly falling down dead after a car passed by… The exhaust may cause some poor long term exposure risks, both for humans and the environment. But, wow did you lean into that script and performance…I’d hate to think of the utter panic and hysteria one would have to perform, if the script involved nuclear weapons, or small pox, hypergolic fuels, or any number of truly nasty chemicals or things…


…Yeah maybe it would have been wise to be a bit more rational in the writing, I know this is entertainment, but maybe being truthful is better… Especially when over stating the danger something is to humans and the environment, others will try and take advantages of these mistakes to label supporters, as liars…

Just a thought. Overall love the channel!
So nice

I think that they (science) will find that catalysis may also be mediated by topology as well as elemental properties. We see hints of this in the many uses for graphene (skewed layers display new properties as a whole compared to a single layer). And topological color (iridescence in birds and insects) which is color produced by the physical nanostructure of the surface instead of only from absorption and re-emmission of photons by the chemical itself.

Rose Bear Don't Walk might just be my favorite SciShow host! Thanks for another great video! I really appreciate the attention you all draw to the unsung heroes of science, particularly those from historically underrepresented groups.

Liked the clip.  As a Chemist, I'm chagrined having to admit to not hearing of this gal, Fulhame was it?  Learn something new every day.  Started my college some 50 years now, back.  I recall ol' Doc Willard in my Freshman Chemistry class emphasizing the change from Alchemy to Chemistry, which occurred when John Dalton offered several methods of how an element might be measured, might be determined to be an element.  How to measure what is now referred to as the 'atomic weight' of an element and so on.  So, in effect, then, Chemistry at that point became less magic and more science.  I gather that back in the day, you would have a hard time telling the specific differences between the two notions.  There's a quip that I once heard... from somewhere.  To the effect that 'if you can't put a number on it, then it's an opinion, not a fact.'  John Dalton did that.

love how in-depth she went in on the catalytic converter, really getting down to the "nuts & bolts" of it.. instead of just, ya' know~ mentioning it as a mere side-note by simply glossing over the surface of it with a sentence-length description..essentially just regergitating the most basic understanding of it which everyone pretty much already knows off hand. so yeah, thats good.

on the other hand, maybe the most good that comes of this is actually how society may just have been gifted [ x ] amount of people who as of viewing this video, (hopefully) now no longer refer to this wonderful nifty invention as a "CADILLAC -converter".
....plz, let us all just leave the godd@mned cadillacs out of this. no, your P.O.S hoopty will not one day be magically 'converted' into a christ-loving CADILLAC by way of some mysterious box located in the middle of your exhaust system. for god sakes

Stuff like this makes me wish I was born earlier, or later I guess, when making scientific breakthroughs didn't require so much funding for both materials but also access to knowledge. I want to make plant based medicine for instance, but even basic testing is too expensive for me and a clinical trial is completely out of reach. Even the research done by others, for instance case studies of a rare autoimmune condition I might actually have according to my Dr, further tests pending, are behind paywalls and are the only resources that exist. Feels like if you're not a high degree holder and employed by some big institution or corporation you're just not permitted to do certain types of science anymore.

Before everyone is like "another man stealing the work of another women", I would chalk it up more to slow translation rate and lack of digital pre-study research for scientific study during that time. Remember, these are not drama novels or political manifestos. Yes even in Enlightened Europe people still had a higher demand for non-chemistry related material. It took four years just to translate her book to be published in Germany. Jons was Swedish and there was already a mountains of publications that that just his country was going through in term of science. This is like Chou Pei discovering the Pythagorean theorem.
This is called the multiple discovery problem. In both cases the age of the internet has provided two things that would have resolved this problem ASAP: a search engine and digital translator.

I'm conflicted by this video because I think they are forcing a discovery onto a woman for the sake of feminism. Saying she discovered catalysts is like saying a chimp in a forest fire discovered fire. Fulmane observed it but had no understanding of the process. It wouldn't make a difference that she was a woman if she actually discovered it, but I think she only observed it and later it was realized what she observed was the action of catalysts.
Science has no gender.

Sounds like possible historical revisionism to me. The process has been described well before Fulham. I hear no good arguments as to why her description should be more appropriate than the past descriptions. Further, your sources include, from what I can tell, several blog posts and 1 (one) scholarly article that even so much as mentions Fulhame. The other scholarly articles does not mention Fulhame. Surely there must be more source material to back up the claim you’re making here.
